subject: RE: [junit] Constructing JUnit tests from test data

messageBody:
Sure, but don't you *want* a large number of test cases?
The point is that they can be created by a factory method
from the lines in the test data file; you don't have to
write code for each and every one.

- George

-----Original Message-----
From: Lyndon Drake [mailto:lyndon@...]
Sent: Thursday, February 15, 2001 11:08 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Constructing JUnit tests from test data


Won't this result in a rather large number of TestCase objects being
created (and presumably garbage collected eventually)?


On 15 Feb 2001 09:06:27 -0500, Dinwiddie, George wrote:
> Lyndon,
>
> Off the top of my head, I think I'd write a class that extends TestSuite
> and initializes itself from the file, creating a new TestCase from each
> line in the test data file.
>
> - George
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Lyndon Drake [mailto:lyndon@...]
> Sent: Thursday, February 15, 2001 8:03 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Constructing JUnit tests from test data
>
>
> Hi,
>
> I have a large file of test data pairs, consisting of input and expected
> output. I want to use JUnit to test a function which operates on the
> input, and compare the output of the function with the expected output
> for each test data pair.
>
> I can easily write a test method which will iterate over the test data,
> but as soon as one piece of test data causes a test failure the test
> will terminate. I wish to have a separate JUnit test executed for each
> line of test data, which will generate information on the proportion of
> test data instances passed and failed (instead of the current situation,
> where I only know whether the entire test data set has passed or
> failed). In other words, whenever the function fails on a line of test
> data, I want to increment the failure count, while continuing on to
> check all the other lines of test data.
>
> The only idea that has occurred to me is to write a small program that
> will generate a JUnit test class based on the test data: that is, it
> will generate one test function per line of input. This seems
> inefficient in terms of code size (I have many thousands of test
> instances already, and may have several million in the longer term).
>
> JUnit is being used throughout the project, so I want to use JUnit for
> this testing if possible.
>
> Can anyone suggest a way to get this working?
>
> Thanks,
> Lyndon
